awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Developing and Testing an Incubator for Digital Entrepreneurship in Remote Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract: Public 

This collaborative award supports research to design and evaluate a model for entrepreneurial small-business accelerator optimized for job creation in remote Alaskan communities, in collaboration with indigenous populations. Specific objectives and outcomes of this project include:
*	To conduct two workshops with large-scale community involvement in Noorvik, Alaska and Arviat, Nunavut gathering and linking data to the Exchange for Local Observations and Knowledge of the Arctic (ELOKA) project related to comparative US/Canadian venture capital investment potential in the North American Arctic.
*	To develop a digital incubator/accelerator model specifically optimized towards preparing North American indigenous Arctic entrepreneurs to start businesses in the creative and cultural sectors.
Diversifying and strengthening Alaska's economy aligns strongly with U.S. Arctic Policy for national security and economic development. Alaska is a frontier market with extensive untapped creative entrepreneurial assets. Drawing from existing rural and Pan-Arctic business innovation and research, coupled with direct work with Alaskan communities, the IdEA initiative works to grow the Alaskan economy for the transformative benefit of the United States Arctic and potentially other rural communities in the United States. In addition, this research project will also provide key insights into the infusion of training in entrepreneurship into diverse undergraduate and graduate experiences, as the NSF Strategic Plan 2018-2022 notes such training "can speed the translation of new discoveries into commercial applications" and greatly benefit the nation. 

Abstract: Technical  

The (IdEA) Incubator for Digital Entrepreneurship in the Arctic works with remote Alaskan communities to co-produce transformative digitally-focused and economically-centered knowledge developing a digital incubator/accelerator connecting Alaskan rural entrepreneurs with venture capital. The proposed research activities permit comparative cross-pollination of concepts related to Pan-Arctic labor market opportunities for economic development potential, technological capacity, and cultural capital. The incubator leverages multidisciplinary mixed-methodological community-centered approaches to develop and test coproduction of a framework for scientific and economic knowledge in the field of Community Informatics. IdEA applies optimized entrepreneurial training linking entrepreneurship best practices with venture capital support, enabling rural Alaskan communities to develop and apply their unique expertise for the specific purpose of growing and diversifying their economy in alignment with U.S. Arctic Policy for national security and economic development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of North Dakota Main Campus

por.por_cntn:
NSF Award Abstract #1758781 EAGER: Collaborative Research: Developing and Testing an Incubator for Digital Entrepreneurship in Remote Communities.  

This collaborative award supports research to design and evaluate a model for entrepreneurial small-business accelerators optimized for job creation in remote Alaskan communities, in collaboration with indigenous populations. Specific objectives of the project work to provide the opportunity for underserved populations to access the tools and expertise to succeed in digital content production and creative entrepreneurship. 

Diversifying and strengthening Alaska's economy aligns strongly with U.S. Arctic Policy for national security and economic development. Alaska is a frontier market with extensive untapped creative entrepreneurial assets. Drawing from existing rural and Pan-Arctic business innovation and research, coupled with collaboration with Alaskan and Nunavut communities, the IdEA initiative works to grow the Alaskan economy for the transformative benefit of the United States Arctic. 

Specific objectives and outcomes of this project include conducting workshops with large-scale community involvement in Alaska and Nunavut related to comparative US/Canadian economic potential in the North American Arctic, focused on co-developing a digital incubator/accelerator model specifically optimized towards preparing North American Indigenous Arctic entrepreneurs to start businesses in the creative and cultural sectors.

Workshops were held in Arviat, Nunavut; in Hughes and Huslia Alaska; and in Fairbanks Alaska. These workshops took place in classrooms in the respective communities as well as in remote Arctic regions outside of urban areas.

Community-wide discussions, focus groups, curricular development panels, participatory workshop activities, “marketplaces” of entrepreneurship development, and technological training activities took place over the course of the project. Findings of this work were shared with the communities themselves under data sovereignty guidelines, and where permitted linked with peer-reviewed publications, the larger NSF and IARPC data community, the Arctic Council’s Sustainable Development Working Group (SDWG), the Arctic Polar Forum, Presentations at the Tanana Chiefs Conference Tribal Council, Digital Development workshops, and the NSF Arctic Data Center among other broader impacts.  

The project PIs published in the Routledge/Taylor & Francis Research in Polar Regions book series, in the volume Renewable Economies in the Arctic. Their chapter: Arctic Broadband Connectivity and the Creative Economy: Access, Challenges and Opportunities in Nunavut and Alaska reflects work and insight developed from collaborations and community engagement in this project. A large-scale survey of over 400 participants was conducted as a component of this project working closely with members of the Tanana Chiefs Conference Region of Interior (predominantly Athabascan) Alaska Native Peoples.  

An analysis of the survey measure demonstrated the statistically significant need for enhanced digital infrastructure and reworked digital entrepreneurial and technological education (especially practical technology training) in the region. Two statistical measures were created during this research: Arctic Entrepreneurial Readiness (ER) and Digital Technology (DT) needs and skills, both of which showed high measures of internal consistency. The measures revealed evidence of specific addressable barriers that are currently preventing regional digital economic and small business activity, data which informed curricular development during the project. 

One challenge the team encountered relates to sharing project results that contain sensitive community data. New developments at the NSF Arctic Data Center related to sensitive data sharing hold potential for releasing components of data currently held in trust in the communities. Efforts focused on engaging with best practices addressing the confidential nature of this data resulted in the PI’s service as co-lead in an ADC workshop focused on sensitive Arctic social scientific data uploads. These findings and recommendations were presented at the 2021 Polar Data Forum. 

Additional broader impacts from this work include engaging in activities and meetings with IARPC (Interagency Arctic Research Policy Committee) and multiple teams of this collaborative research network including the Arctic Data subteam, Arctic Field Operations Working Group, Diversity & Inclusion Working Group, Polar Technology Community Forum, and Science Communication Forum. The PIs on this project contributed to the NSF discussion regarding the next 5-year Arctic Research Plan, including participating in meetings and making written recommendations in the Federal Register. These recommendations are directly linked to the research findings from this Alaska and Nunavut fieldwork, and focus on actively involving indigenous populations as research experts and co-PIs.  

Since the start of the award, the project has been closely monitoring and reporting on digital communication developments in the Arctic, as limitations in terms of online education, cost of internet access, lack of data speeds and bandwidth challenges were revealed during the project as major barriers to Arctic economic development. The collaborations developed during this project have resulted in strong relationships with project participant communities that hold promise for future collaborative engagement in curricular projects leveraging ubiquitous digital connectivity in remote Arctic regions outside of urban areas. The possibility of remote-region access to mobile high-speed digital communication that has developed during the time of this project holds significant potential for indigenous Arctic entrepreneurs in enhanced educational, sociocultural, entrepreneurial and other economic opportunities. 


Last Modified: 11/08/2022
Modified by: Timothy Pasch
